awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an integrated Zeiss 980 microscope with Airyscan 2 and FCS to advance multidisciplinary research, inclusive teaching, and outreach at Amherst College
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Amherst College to support the acquisition of a specialized light microscope that provides the resolution to visualize features in cells as small as 120 nm, approximately the size of a SARS-CoV-2 virus, and the ability to analyze the movement of single molecules in living cells. The instrument will expand the scope of research, currently not possible at the College, into exciting new areas. Additionally, the new multifunctional imaging system will be the flagship instrument of a new imaging facility in the recently opened integrated Science Center. The acquired microscope will become a shared resource open to investigators from all areas of scientific research across the community of local colleges and universities. Through the new imaging facility, this instrument will provide hands-on experience for students on a high-end imaging system and will greatly expand the offerings of established pre-matriculation and summer research initiatives aimed at recruiting, training, and retaining underrepresented STEM students on campus. The acquisition of this unique, multifunctional light microscope will not only modernize the institution’s imaging capabilities but will impact classroom offerings across disciplines, including biology, biochemistry, biophysics, and neuroscience. Working in partnership with the Beneski Museum of Natural History, a student-curated exhibit of images and videos will be created, speaking to the intersection of art and science through an initiative entitled “Molecules in Motion” (MiM). This will promote the science of the College’s scientists and students and increase the visibility of the work to the broadest audience while creating awareness of the remarkable developments in STEM to visualize the inner workings of molecules in living cells.

The new fast, multifunctional, high-resolution microscope will transform researchers’ abilities to investigate intermolecular interactions and cellular processes. It will meet the growing demands of a variety of research programs ranging from high resolution studies of dynamic signal transduction and developmental processes in sea anemone and C. elegans to investigations of ultrafast cellular and organismal responses in neurons and zebrafish. The instrument’s capabilities to stimulate with light will enable studies of neural encoding of auditory function and motile responses to environmental stimuli in Dictyostellium. Access to single molecule dynamics will enable cross-disciplinary collaborations between chemistry around the application of custom fluorescent labels for biological imaging and investigations into the consequences of zinc dysregulation on amyloid protein in vitro and in neurons. This new microscope will amplify the researchers’ abilities to leverage their unique strengths in research, outreach, and training to bridge impactful scientific discoveries to a profound and enduring impact on the community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The acquisition of the ZEISS 980 confocal microscope has profoundly transformed research and education at Amherst College, becoming a cornerstone of the Amherst Biological Imaging Center (ABIC). Over the course of this award, the instrument has established itself as an indispensable tool for faculty and student research, contributing significantly to publications, curriculum development, and community engagement. In its third year, the ZEISS 980’s integration into academic programs, research projects, and outreach initiatives has created a ripple effect across disciplines and the broader community.

The ZEISS 980 has been instrumental in advancing research at Amherst College. In Year 3 alone, more than 50 researchers from 10 labs across four departments utilized the instrument for a total of 2,900 hours. This extensive use highlights the ZEISS 980’s central role in molecular and cellular research on campus. Its high-resolution imaging capabilities have supported cutting-edge scientific discoveries, contributing to journal publications, conference presentations, and grant proposals. Notable examples include studies published in prestigious journals such as Current Biology and PNAS, showcasing the instrument’s ability to enable impactful research.

One of the most significant impacts of the ZEISS 980 has been its integration into the curriculum, providing students with hands-on experience using advanced imaging technologies. In Year 3, approximately 150 students across four courses—including the introductory Molecules, Genes, and Cells course and advanced classes in neuroscience, cellular biology, and molecular biology—engaged with the instrument for more than 80 hours. These courses introduced students to foundational concepts in microscopy and advanced techniques such as confocal imaging, super-resolution methods, and live-cell imaging. These experiences have equipped students with valuable skills, preparing them for careers and further studies in STEM fields.

The ZEISS 980’s influence extends well beyond research and classroom instruction. The first phase of the “Molecules in Motion” initiative, implemented in Year 3, brought the campus community together through a research symposium and photomicroscopy competition. This initiative, developed in collaboration with the Mead Art Museum, showcased stunning images generated with the ZEISS 980. Students, with guidance from museum curators, designed the exhibit, which was featured as part of a larger art series displayed in the Science Center and dining commons. Faculty, staff, and students from various departments, including Geology, Art, History of Art, Biology, and Architecture, participated in the event. Guest judges lent their expertise, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and highlighting the broader applications of imaging in both science and art.

The ZEISS 980 has also played a vital role in supporting Amherst College’s workforce development initiatives. Participants in programs such as the Clare Luce Booth Scholars program, the STEM Incubator, and the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) program received training on the instrument, gaining hands-on experience with advanced imaging techniques. Additionally, the instrument supported thesis research and summer internships funded by the Greg Call Intern Fellowship, further enhancing its impact on student development.

By providing access to advanced imaging technologies, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration, and equipping students with valuable skills, the ZEISS 980 has redefined the research and educational landscape at Amherst College. Its integration into the curriculum and broader campus initiatives has ensured that the instrument’s impact extends far beyond the laboratory, enriching the academic and cultural fabric of the college. As Amherst continues to leverage this powerful tool, the ZEISS 980 will undoubtedly remain a cornerstone of research and education for years to come.
